title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.25-27 | 07-01-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Mirandhasya Gyanan Janishalakaya Chakshurunmeelitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, setting a spiritual tone.

segments.key_quote: Thus you descend as an incarnation to remove the burden of the world and to benefit your friends especially those who are your exclusive devotees and are wrapped in meditation upon you.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces verse 25, explaining Arjuna's prayer describing Krishna's descent as an incarnation to relieve the world's burden and benefit exclusive devotees.

segments.key_quote: The Lord is everyone's father, aham bijapratapitah that's what Krishna says in Bhagavad Gita, he is the seed-giving Father of all living entities.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the Lord's relationship with all beings, emphasizing that while He is equal to everyone, He is more inclined towards His devotees, who are considered His kinsmen.

segments.key_quote: This is his transcendental pastime, it is pastime, this is Leela and it has nothing to do with mundane ideas of relations, fatherhood or anything like that.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that Krishna's relationships and pastimes are transcendental and should not be understood through a material lens, as the Lord is above the modes of material nature.

segments.key_quote: O Lord of Lords, he has addressed Krishna as Deva Deva. He is the Lord of Lords. Krishna is Lord of Lords. How is it that this dangerous effulgence is spreading all around? Where does it come from? I do not understand it.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces verse 26, focusing on Arjuna's question about a dangerous effulgence and highlighting the importance of offering prayers before addressing the Lord, even for intimate friends.

segments.key_quote: Know from me that this is the act of the son of Drona. He has thrown the hymns of nuclear energy, Brahmastra, and he does not know how to retract the glare.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces verse 27, explaining Krishna's response about the Brahmastra released by Ashwathama, comparing it to a modern nuclear weapon and emphasizing its creation through subtle sound (mantras).

segments.key_quote: The subtle science of chanting hymns is also material, this Brahmastra is released by a subtle method of chanting a mantra but it is a material phenomenon.
segments.summary: The speaker distinguishes between the subtle material science used to create the Brahmastra and the transcendental nature of spiritual mantras like Hare Krishna, highlighting the limitations of modern science.

segments.key_quote: A chanter of hymns knew how to apply the weapon as well as how to retract it see that is the special thing about this the science of subtle sound that they knew how to release it and how to withdraw it also retract it that was perfect knowledge
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts spiritual chanting with the material use of mantras for weapons, emphasizing that true knowledge includes both application and retraction, which Ashwathama lacked, making his use of the Brahmastra improper and irreligious.

segments.key_quote: As the son of a Brahmana he should not have made so many mistakes it all began with what Ashwathama beheading the sons of Draupadi while they were sleeping totally religious totally against all the codes of Dharma Yudha
segments.summary: The speaker details Ashwathama's transgressions, starting with the beheading of Draupadi's sons, highlighting his violation of religious principles and the consequences he faces, including Krishna's impending punishment and Arjuna's role in retracting the Brahmastra.

segments.key_quote: There are a lot of lessons to be learned from this particular incident being described here in the beginning of the Bhagavatam when Suta Goswami is narrating the events leading to Pariksit meeting with Shukadev Goswami where he inquired about this subject matter of Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing the valuable lessons contained within this narrative from the Srimad Bhagavatam, setting the stage for future discussions.
